title: The Daily Standup: Beyond Status Updates
thesis: Effective daily standups focus on collaboration and removing blockers, not just status reporting

sections.title: The Purpose of Daily Standups
sections.description: Daily standups exist to synchronize the team, identify blockers, and enable collaboration. This section explains why standups matter beyond mere status reporting and how they accelerate team velocity when done right.

sections.title: The Three Classic Questions (And Why They're Not Enough)
sections.description: The traditional format asks: What did you do yesterday? What will you do today? What's blocking you? While useful, this structure often devolves into mechanical status updates that miss the collaboration opportunity.

subsections.title: Moving Beyond Status Reports
subsections.description: Effective standups shift focus from individual reporting to team problem-solving. Teams should discuss dependencies, offer help, and coordinate work rather than simply reciting task lists.

subsections.title: Time-boxing and Efficiency
subsections.description: Keep standups to 15 minutes maximum. Longer meetings indicate deeper issues: too many team members, lack of focus, or discussions that belong elsewhere. Parking lot items for post-standup follow-up.

sections.title: Common Antipatterns and How to Avoid Them
sections.description: Standups fail in predictable ways. Recognizing these patterns helps teams course-correct before dysfunction becomes habit.

subsections.title: The Status Report Trap
subsections.description: When standups become one-way broadcasts to a manager, engagement drops and value disappears. Fix this by having team members speak to each other, not to leadership.

subsections.title: Going Into the Weeds
subsections.description: Detailed technical discussions derail standups. Save implementation details for focused working sessions with relevant team members only.

subsections.title: Skipping Blocked Work
subsections.description: Teams often gloss over blockers or fail to follow up. Make blocker resolution the highest priority outcome of every standup.

sections.title: Best Practices for Effective Standups
sections.description: Successful standups follow patterns that maximize value while minimizing time investment.

subsections.title: Stand Up (Literally)
subsections.description: Physical discomfort keeps meetings short. Remote teams can use virtual backgrounds or other visual cues to maintain the same time pressure.

subsections.title: Same Time, Same Place
subsections.description: Consistency reduces coordination overhead. Make standups a non-negotiable calendar fixture at a time that works for all team members, including remote participants.

subsections.title: Focus on Today and Tomorrow
subsections.description: Yesterday's work is history. Emphasize what's happening now and what's coming next to keep the team forward-looking.

subsections.title: Make Blockers Visible
subsections.description: Use a physical or digital board to track impediments. Assign owners to each blocker and review resolution progress daily until cleared.

sections.title: Adapting Standups for Remote Teams
sections.description: Distributed teams require intentional modifications to maintain standup effectiveness across time zones and communication mediums.

subsections.title: Async Standups
subsections.description: For globally distributed teams, written updates in Slack or similar tools can replace synchronous meetings. Set clear expectations for update timing and format.

subsections.title: Video vs. Audio vs. Text
subsections.description: Video provides the richest context but creates timezone challenges. Audio works for moderate time zone spreads. Text works best for maximal async flexibility.

subsections.title: Maintaining Team Connection
subsections.description: Remote standups risk becoming transactional. Build in moments for casual interaction and team bonding without extending meeting time excessively.
